explanation:
Why each symbol is required for checking the MISRA C rule (controlling expressions shall not be invariant):

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET
  - Needed to understand how "impl" is obtained from the token; although not a controlling expression itself, the macro expansion could have side effects or constant semantics that affect whether later tests (e.g. impl->fd < 0 or impl->selectable assignment) are invariant.

- OS_impl_filehandle_table
  - Used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its definition/contents may affect the result of the macro and thereby whether impl (and any of its fields) can be treated as invariant.

- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
  - Required to know the types and meanings of impl->fd and impl->selectable. Determining whether checks like (impl->fd < 0) or the assignment to impl->selectable are based on invariant data requires the structure definition.

- OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE
  - Appears in the controlling expressions (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE). Its value and definition are required to decide if that expression can ever vary (or if it is effectively a constant mask yielding an invariant result).

- OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE
  - Same reason as OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE; used in a controlling expression (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE) so its value matters for deciding invariance.

- OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS
  - Explicitly OR'ed into os_perm before the open call. If this macro includes O_NONBLOCK or other bits, it can force os_perm (and thus the subsequent selectable test) to a value that makes the controlling expression invariant.

- OS_READ_ONLY, OS_WRITE_ONLY, OS_READ_WRITE
  - The switch(access_mode) uses these constants. Their numeric values (and whether any are identical or constant-foldable) are needed to determine whether the switch controlling expression is potentially invariant or degenerate.

- O_WRONLY, O_RDONLY, O_RDWR, O_CREAT, O_TRUNC
  - These are the OS/file flags used to build os_perm. Their values affect whether os_perm can vary with input flags/access_mode or whether it is effectively constant after the macro combinations.

- O_NONBLOCK
  - Used in the final selectable determination: ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0). If O_NONBLOCK is present in OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS (or otherwise forced on), this test becomes invariant. Its definition is therefore essential.

Overall rationale: the MISRA rule targets controlling expressions that are invariant (i.e., compile-time or effectively constant). The controlling expressions in this function are: the switch(access_mode), the two tests (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE) and (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE), and the selectable test ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0). To decide if any of these are invariant we must know the exact definitions/values of the macros and types that determine os_perm, flags, and access_mode interpretation; the symbols above are the minimal set that can affect whether these controlling expressions can be constant.
